context: <a0_0><a0_1><a0_2><b5_0>John Paul II<b5_0/><a0_2/><a0_1/><a0_0/>'s visits to his native country in 1979 and 1983 brought support to the budding solidarity movement and encouraged the <a1_0><a1_2><b6_0>growing <a1_1>anti-communist fervor<b6_0/><a1_2/><a1_1/><a1_0/> there. In <a3_2>1979<a3_2/>, <a2_0><a2_1><a2_2><b7_0>less than a year<b7_0/><a2_2/><a2_1/><a2_0/> after becoming pope, John Paul celebrated Mass in <a3_0><a3_1><b8_0>Victory Square<b8_0/><a3_1/><a3_0/> in Warsaw and ended his sermon with a call to "renew the face" of Poland: Let Thy Spirit descend! Let Thy Spirit descend and renew the face of the land! This land! These words were very meaningful for the Polish citizens who understood them as the <a4_0><a4_1><b9_0>incentive for the <a4_2>democratic changes<b9_0/><a4_2/><a4_1/><a4_0/>.
